title: 113_hr1409
content: The Export Promotion Reform Act, also known as the "Export Promotion Reform Act," aims to improve coordination of export promotion activities among federal agencies. Section 2312 of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include a review of proposed annual budgets of agencies by the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee before submission to the Office of Management and Budget and the President. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee (TPCC) is required to review proposed annual budgets of agencies before submission to the Office of Management and Budget and the President. The TPCC must also consider recommendations from US exporters, especially small and medium-sized businesses, and US workers. The President is tasked with ensuring that the TPCC fulfills its duties and implements a strategic plan. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee (TPCC) reviews agency budgets before submission to the Office of Management and Budget and the President. The TPCC considers recommendations from US exporters, particularly small and medium-sized businesses, and US workers. The President ensures the TPCC fulfills its duties and implements a strategic plan, defining 'small business' as per the Small Business Act. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DEPLOYMENT OF U.S. COMMERCIAL SERVICE RESOURCES. Section 2301(c)(4) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to conduct a global assessment of overseas markets for increasing US exports and deploying Commercial Service personnel and resources accordingly. The Secretary must conduct a global assessment of overseas markets for increasing US exports and deploy Commercial Service personnel and resources based on the assessment every 5 years. Additionally, a plan for deployment must be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the Export Promotion Reform Act's enactment. "Strengthened U.S. commercial diplomacy to support U.S. exports." The amendment to the Foreign Service Act of 1980 includes the development of a plan for effective diplomacy to promote exports of U.S. goods and services, assessments of efforts to promote exports, and changes to the Inspector General's role. The Foreign Service Act of 1980 is amended to include evaluating the effectiveness of commercial diplomacy in promoting exports of U.S. goods and services.
